user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
struct metal_irq_controller {
	int irq_base; /**< Start of IRQ number of the range managed by
		 	* the IRQ controller
		 	*/
	int irq_num; /**< Number of IRQs managed by the IRQ controller */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to interrupt controller function */
	metal_irq_set_enable irq_set_enable; /**< function to set IRQ enable */
	metal_cntr_irq_register irq_register; /**< function to register IRQ
						* handler
						*/
	struct metal_list node; /**< list node */
	struct metal_irq *irqs; /**< Array of IRQs managed by the controller */
}
...
static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(linux_irq_cntr,
				    0, MAX_IRQS,
				    NULL,
				    metal_linux_irq_set_enable, NULL,
				    irqs)
...
static metal_mutex_t irq_lock
...
static unsigned long
irqs_enabled[metal_div_round_up(MAX_IRQS, METAL_BITS_PER_ULONG)]
...
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in metal_linux_irq_set_enable. Analysis of each parameter: 
- irq_cntr: only dereferenced for read-only comparisons (irq_cntr->irq_base, irq_cntr->irq_num); there is no assignment to irq_cntr itself (no irq_cntr = ..., no increment/decrement). Dereferencing and reading the object is allowed; modifying the object pointed to would be allowed, but no such modification occurs here. 
- irq: used only in comparisons and in the calculation of offset; there is no assignment to irq (no irq = ..., no ++/--). 
- state: only compared (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE); not assigned or altered.

Called functions (metal_bitmap_set_bit, metal_bitmap_clear_bit, metal_mutex_acquire/release, metal_linux_irq_notify, metal_log) do not receive any of these parameters by address for modification. The only local variables (offset, ret) are modified as locals. 

Therefore, there are no code fragments in the provided function that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. (Note: the offset calculation uses the global linux_irq_cntr rather than the irq_cntr parameter which may be a logic bug, but it does not relate to modifying a function parameter.)
